awd_titl_txt: IRES Track III: Global Engineering Education Exchange Graduate International Research Experiences (Global E? GIRE)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Institute of International Education (IIE) to manage the Global Engineering Education Exchange Graduate International Research Experiences (Global E3 GIRE) program. The program supports research experiences abroad for American graduate students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields to develop the knowledge and skills to succeed in a globalized world while increasing collective scientific knowledge, thus enhancing U.S. economic competitiveness. Students are introduced to new research approaches and methods in an international setting, which improves their expertise and qualifications as scientists and engineers, and allows them to contribute to the global scientific community. Expanding the international perspectives of future STEM leaders in the U.S. enables them to produce creative, original, and collaborative work that will advance America's scientific knowledge and pursue solutions to shared global problems. Emerging American STEM leaders build relationships with their peers in other countries through long-term collaborative research, which in turn leads to future partnerships between the global host institutions participating in Global E3 GIRE and the current and future research institutions with which the U.S. participants are affiliated.

The Global E3 GIRE program enhances U.S. leadership in STEM education and strengthens economic competitiveness by developing America's STEM researchers and future leaders who are not only superb engineers and scientists, but also have the research knowledge and skills, cross-cultural leadership, communication abilities, and international networks to advance STEM innovation in a globalized world. The Institute of International Education (IIE) manages the program, which provides approximately 75 American STEM graduate students from diverse backgrounds, institutions, and fields of study with international long-term research experiences and short-term study tours between fall 2018 and summer 2021. Participants hone their research skills through exposure to international methods and approaches, develop global competencies such as intercultural leadership and communication abilities, expand their professional networks of host country peers and participants from other U.S. institutions, and gain exposure to private sector STEM employers. Through outreach and support for U.S. faculty advisors, the program encourages their international activities and networks as well, while also promoting their ongoing support for graduate student research abroad.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Institute of International Education? (IIE?) launched the IIE-GIRE (Graduate International Research Experiences) program in 2019 with grant funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) (grant number 1829436).

The overarching goals of the IIE - GIRE (Graduate International Research Experiences) program were closely aligned with the IRES Track III goals in implementing, evaluating, and disseminating an innovative large-scale program and model for providing high-quality international research and research-related professional development experiences to U.S. graduate students.

Specific to the IIE-GIRE Fellowship, the fulfilled goals of project were to:

  • Help to develop American STEM leaders who are not only superb engineers and scientists, but also have the research knowledge and skills, cross-cultural leadership and communication ability, and international networks to advance STEM innovation in a globalized world. 
  • Select and connect American STEM graduate students from diverse backgrounds, institutions, and fields of study with international research opportunities and research-related professional development experiences.
  • Rigorously monitore and evaluate the program impact to identify best practices and lessons learned and expand the knowledge base on internationalization of STEM education and research.

IE-GIRE achieved these goals by supporting U.S. engineering graduate students and their academic advisors for graduate student research experiences abroad. From 2019 to 2022, the IIE-GIRE program funded three cohorts of engineering graduate students.

Over the thre cohorts, the IIE-GIRE program allowed 34 U.S. STEM doctoral students to travel abroad to perform research at an international host institution. Performing the research at an international institution allowed the Fellows to access equipment, learn techniques from other labs, and build international science networks they would not have access to at their home institutions. In addition, the program awarded each of the 34 Fellow Home Faculty Advisors a stipend to either visit the Fellow at their Host Institution to further build relationships or advance internationalization activities within their home department. The Fellows came from 23 different U.S. Home Institutions and worked at 33 different International Host Institutions in 13 countries.
